loco 0.0.0.9000
  • Reference

Calculate local correlation scores

Source: R/loco.R
loco.Rd

Calculate local correlation (LoCo) scores for a pair of time series.

Usage

loco(
  .data,
  x,
  y,
  timestamps = NULL,
  demean = TRUE,
  window_size,
  decay = 0.95,
  exp_window = TRUE,
  k
)

Arguments

.data

A data frame or a data frame extension (e.g. a tibble).

x, y

Names of the columns containing the time series data, as symbols.

timestamps

An optional parameter specifying the name of the column, as a symbol, containing timestamps corresponding to x and y.

demean

Subtract the series' respective means from the time series values. Defaults to TRUE.

window_size

The size of the window to use when calculating autocovariances.

decay

The exponential decay factor used to downweight historic time windows when using an exponential sliding window. Should be a value strictly between 0 (most decay) and 1 (least decay). Ignored if exp_window is FALSE.

exp_window

Should an exponential sliding window be used? Defaults to TRUE. If FALSE, a sliding (a.k.a. boxcar) window is used.

k

The number of principal eigenvectors to consider when calculating the LoCo scores. Value should be an integer between 1 and window_size.

Value

A tibble with columns timestamps (if supplied) and scores.

Details

The LoCo score is an extension of the linear cross-correlation coefficient and measures the local similarity (concurrent alignment) between two time series using the spectral decompositions of local autocovariance matrices. The LoCo score is a value between 0 (weak alignment) and 1 (strong alignment).

References

Papadimitriou, S., Sun, J., and Yu, P.S. (2006) Local Correlation Tracking in Time Series. Proceedings of the Sixth International Conference on Data Mining (ICDM'06). doi:10.1109/ICDM.2006.99.
